ResourceHeader.Description: DMSP F15 (USA 147) was launched by a Titan rocket from Vandenberg AFB on December 12, 1999 into a 101 minute, sun-synchronous near-polar orbit at an altitude of 840km and with the Local Time nodes of 21:10 and 9:10. The Defense Meteorological Satellite Program (DMSP) is a Department of Defense (DoD) program run by the Air Force Space and Missle Systems Center (SMC). The program designs, builds, launches, and maintains satellites monitoring the meteorological, oceanographic, and solar-terrestrial physics environments. Each DMSP satellite has a above the surface of the earth. The visible and infrared sensors (OLS) collect images across a 3000 km swath, providing global coverage twice per day. The combination of day/night and dawn/dusk satellites allows monitoring of global information such as clouds every 6 hours. The microwave imager (MI) and sounders (T1, T2) cover one half the width of the visible and infrared swath. These instruments cover polar regions at least twice and the equatorial region once per day. The space environment sensors (J4, M, IES) record along-track plasma densities, velocities, composition and drifts. The data from the DMSP satellites are received and used at operational centers continuously. The data are sent to the National Geophysical Data Center's Solar Terrestrial Physics Division (NGDC/STP) by the Air Force Weather Agency (AFWA) for creation of an archive.
ResourceHeader.Acknowledgement: DMSP Data Manager, NOAA National Environmental Satellite, Data, and Information Service, NESDIS

InformationURL.Description: Defense Meteorological Satellite Program, DMSP-F15, Information and Details

InformationURL.Name: Defense Meteorological Satellite Program, Block 5D-3 Spacecraft Overview
InformationURL.Description: Detailed information on the Defense Meteorological Satellite Program 5D-3 satellite series.

ResourceHeader.Description: DMSP/F15, Operational Linescan System, OLS, The OLS measures visible (0.4-1.1 micrometers) and infrared (10.25-12.6 micrometers) wavelengths to provide day and night cloud cover imagery. The satellite measures data at a 0.56 km resolution, which is averaged on board, to produce global coverage at 2.7 km resolution. All of the 2.7 km resolution (smooth) data is downlinked to the ground sites while a small amount of the 0.56 km resolution (fine) data is stored and downlinked. The OLS is the primary sensor on each DMSP satellite.
ResourceHeader.Acknowledgement: DMSP Data Manager, NOAA National Environmental Satellite, Data, and Information Service, NESDIS

InformationURL.Name: Operational Linescan System Web Site
InformationURL.Description: Operational Linescan System, OLS, Information and Details

ResourceHeader.Description: DMSP_5D3-F15 spacecraft positions in various coordinate systems

ResourceHeader.ResourceName: DMSP/F15, Special Sensor Microwave Water Vapor Profiler, SSM/T-2
ResourceHeader.Description: DMSP/F15, Special Sensor Microwave Water Vapor Profiler, SSM/T-2, The SSM/T-2 water profiler sensor is a five channel, total power microwave radiometer designed to provide global monitoring of water vapor concentration in the atmosphere under all conditions. With two window channels and three channels in the 183.31 GHz water vapor resonance line, SSM/T-2 is able to capitalize on the reduced sensitivity of the microwave region to cloud attenuation.
ResourceHeader.Acknowledgement: DMSP Data Manager, NOAA National Environmental Satellite, Data, and Information Service, NESDIS

InformationURL.Name: Special Sensor Microwave Water Vapor Profiler Web Site
InformationURL.Description: Special Sensor Microwave Water Vapor Profiler, SSM/T-2, Information and Details

ResourceHeader.ResourceName: DMSP/F15, Special Sensor Microwave Temperature Sounder, SSM/T
ResourceHeader.Description: DMSP/F15, Special Sensor Microwave Temperature Sounder, SSM/T, The SSM/T is a seven channel, cross track nadir scanning passive microwave sounder having a field of view of 14.4 degrees. It measures the Earth's surface and atmospheric emission in the 50 to 60 GHz oxygen band. At nominal altitude, the subtrack spatial resolution is a circle of 174 km at nadir and an ellipse of 213x304 km toward the limb. There are seven total cross-track scan positions separated by 12 degrees at frequencies 50.5, 53.2, 54.35, 54.9, 58.4, 58.825 and 59.4 GHz.
ResourceHeader.Acknowledgement: DMSP Data Manager, NOAA National Environmental Satellite, Data, and Information Service, NESDIS

InformationURL.Name: Special Sensor Microwave Temperature Sounder Web Site
InformationURL.Description: Special Sensor Microwave Temperature Sounder, SSM/T, Information and Details

ResourceHeader.ResourceName: DMSP/F15, Special Sensor Microwave Imager, SSM/I
ResourceHeader.Description: DMSP/F15, Special Sensor Microwave Imager, SSM/I, The SSM/I is a seven-channel, four-frequency, orthogonally polarized, passive microwave radiometric system that measures atmospheric, ocean and terrain microwave brightness temperatures at 19.35, 22.2, 37.0, and 85.5 GHz.
ResourceHeader.Acknowledgement: DMSP Data Manager, NOAA National Environmental Satellite, Data, and Information Service, NESDIS

InformationURL.Name: Special Sensor Microwave Imager Web Site
InformationURL.Description: Special Sensor Microwave Imager, SSM/I, Information and Details

ResourceHeader.ResourceName: DMSP/F15, Gamma Ray Particle Detector, SSB/X-2
ResourceHeader.Description: DMSP/F15, Gamma Ray Particle Detector, SSB/X-2, The SSB/X-2 is an array-based system that detects the location, intensity, and spectrum of X-rays emitted from the Earth's atmosphere.
ResourceHeader.Acknowledgement: DMSP Data Manager, NOAA National Environmental Satellite, Data, and Information Service, NESDIS

InformationURL.Name: Gamma Ray Particle Detector Web Site
InformationURL.Description: Gamma Ray Particle Detector, SSB/X-2, Information and Details

ResourceHeader.ResourceName: DMSP/F15, SEM Special Sensor Ionospheric Plasma Drift/Scintillation Monitor-2, SEM/SSI/ES-2
ResourceHeader.Description: DMSP/F15, SEM Special Sensor Ionospheric Plasma Drift/Scintillation Monitor-2, SEM/SSI/ES-2, The SSI/ES measures the ambient electron density and temperatures, ambient ion density, the average ion temperature and molecular weight, the plasma drift and scintillation at the DMSP orbital altitude.
ResourceHeader.Acknowledgement: DMSP Data Manager, NOAA National Environmental Satellite, Data, and Information Service, NESDIS

InformationURL.Name: SEM Special Sensor Ionospheric Plasma Drift/Scintillation Monitor-2 Web Site
InformationURL.Description: SEM Special Sensor Ionospheric Plasma Drift/Scintillation Monitor-2, SEM/SSI/ES-2, Information and Details

ResourceHeader.ResourceName: DMSP/F15, SEM Special Sensor Precipitating Electron and Ion Spectrometer 4, SEM/SSJ4
ResourceHeader.Description: DMSP/F15, SEM Special Sensor Precipitating Electron and Ion Spectrometer 4, SEM/SSJ4, The SSJ/4 measures the transfer energy, mass, and momentum through the magnetosphere-ionosphere in the Earth's magnetic field. The SSJ/4 sensor consists of four electrostatic analyzers that record the flux of precipitating ions or electrons at 20 fixed energy channels between 50 eV and 30 keV.
ResourceHeader.Acknowledgement: DMSP Data Manager, NOAA National Environmental Satellite, Data, and Information Service, NESDIS

InformationURL.Name: SEM Special Sensor Precipitating Electron and Ion Spectrometer 4 Web Site
InformationURL.Description: SEM Special Sensor Precipitating Electron and Ion Spectrometer 4, SEM/SSJ4, Information and Details

ResourceHeader.ResourceName: DMSP/F15, SESS Special Sensor Magnetometer-Boom, SESS/SSM-Boom
ResourceHeader.Description: DMSP/F15, SESS Special Sensor Magnetometer-Boom, SESS/SSM-Boom, The SSM, a triaxial fluxgate magnetometer, measures geomagnetic fluctuations associated with geophysical phenomena.
ResourceHeader.Acknowledgement: DMSP Data Manager, NOAA National Environmental Satellite, Data, and Information Service, NESDIS
